s.text: The studies reported here used a probe that will detect the adult Gad1 mRNA that encodes GAD67 as well as the embryonic alternatively spliced mRNA that can encode GAD25 and GAD44.
Sections were phtotographed using an Olympus BX60 microscope fitted with a SPOT digital camera (Diagnostic Instruments Inc.).
The embryos were photographed without clearing using a Leica model MZFL III dissecting scope, a Hamamatsu model C4742-95 digital camera and Openlab 2.0.
Embryos were removed and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde/PBS overnight and used immediately for the in situ hybridization.
The studies reported here used a probe that will detect the adult Gad1 mRNA that encodes GAD67 as well as the embryonic alternatively spliced mRNA that can encode GAD25 and GAD44.
Control hybridizations using a sense strand Gad1 probe were also performed.
Using a whole mount in situ hybridization approach, we found that Gad1 is indeed expressed in a number of different regions and tissues.
The genetic data strongly suggest that GABA acts through GABA A receptors to modulate the development of this tissue.

The cleft palate phenotype of the Gad1 mutants suggests the involvement of GABA-mediated signals in the normal development and differentiation of a structure derived from the oral epithelium and neural crest ecto-mesenchyme.

The earlier activation of Gad1 in the forelimb reflects the normal temporal order of events in limb development.
The earlier activation of Gad1 in the forelimb reflects the normal temporal order of events in limb development.

The cleft palate phenotype of the Gad1 mutants suggests the involvement of GABA-mediated signals in the normal development and differentiation of a structure derived from the oral epithelium and neural crest ecto-mesenchyme.
In addition to these functions in the developing CNS, GABA signaling is also required for the normal development of non-neural tissues.
Later, during postnatal development, normal GABAergic input is required for activity-dependent plasticity in the visual cortex as shown in the Gad2 knockout mouse [ 15, 16].

Gad1 mRNA translation or protein stability can be regulated in mature neurons by the level of GABA [ 30, 31].

We detected weak staining in the heart and did not detect blood vessel expression, perhaps due to the very low levels of expression in developing vasculature [ 27].
5 embryo revealed a high level of Gad1 expression throughout the mesenchyme and neural epithelium in the caudal portion of the tailbud (figure 1F).
Previous studies have shown that Gad1 can be regulated at the post-transcriptional and translational level.
In the paraxial mesoderm, the highest expression levels were also localized ventrally, adjacent to the notochord (figure 1E).
